description: From French péricarpe, from New Latin pericarpium, from Ancient Greek περικάρπιον (perikárpion, “pod, husk, shell”), from περι- (peri-, “around”) + καρπός (karpós, “fruit”). By surface analysis, peri- +‎ -carp.

entries.meaning: (botany) The outermost layer, or skin, of a ripe fruit or ovary.
(rare, figurative) The outer layer of anything.
examples: He learned, afternoon after afternoon, how to edge her into delicious frenzies, how to tremble the clitoris, pericarp, and tip.
